Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrating Geometric, Probabilistic, and Topological Methods for Phase Space Transport in Dynamical Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to develop a firm unified foundation for the theoretical and computational analysis of the phase space transport problem. Many physical systems can be modeled as having an underlying dynamical skeleton which organizes how all the possible behaviors are related. For systems known analytically with simple time dependence, this skeleton consists of well-known mathematical structures such as invariant sets and sets which asymptotically approach or depart from such sets. But for systems of increasing interest which are non-periodic, based on data, and observed over only a short time, there are no such structures in general. The proposed research will find appropriate analogs to these structures to expand the applicability of dynamical systems results to real world data. Working in the context of fluid flows, we will develop tools using geometric, probabilistic, and topological approaches, including coherent sets, almost-invariant sets, and symbolic dynamics.

Successful completion of this project will provide a new and fruitful approach for conceptualization, visualization, and extraction of information regarding the possible behaviors of a system, with applicability to fluid mechanics and beyond, such as boundaries and transitions between qualitatively different kinds of behavior in data sets defined by meteorological, financial, psychological, or population observations. Education, outreach and dissemination are integral to the project activities, aimed at four audiences: (1) undergraduates will participate in research and develop learning materials for (2) high school students, who will learn about the role of chaotic transport and its relevance in the environment and biology; (3) graduate students and faculty will explore applications of tools from dynamical systems to new problem domains through a project-based course; and the (4) global community of researchers will benefit from numerical tools disseminated online which may reveal previously hidden structure in dynamic data sets.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a unified foundation for the theoretical and computational analysis of the phase space transport problem. “Phase space” is a set of quantifiable parameters which describe a system’s changing state or behavior. The evolution of a system’s behavior in time can be viewed as a curve or trajectory in its phase space. Many physical systems can be modeled as having an underlying dynamical or geometrical “skeleton” which organizes how all the possible behaviors are related. For systems known analytically (as a set of equations with simple mathematical functions) with simple time dependence, this skeleton consists of well-known mathematical structures such as invariant sets and sets which asymptotically approach or depart from such sets. But for systems of increasing interest which are non-periodic, based on experimental data, and observed over only a short time, there are no such structures in general. Our project sought to find appropriate analogs to these structures to expand the applicability of dynamical systems results to real-world data. Working mostly in the context of fluid flows, rigid body dynamics, and multi-body dynamics, we developed tools using geometric, probabilistic, and topological approaches, including coherent sets, almost-invariant sets, and symbolic dynamics.

We considered the performance of trajectory-based, rather than vector-field-based methods for determining phase space structure, with applications to fluid experiments. We found that from sequences of particle images, e.g., from particle image velocimetry (or PIV) fluid experiments, one can directly compute the flow map and coherent structures, skipping the step of constructing a velocity field. This is useful for inertial particles which do not follow fluid velocity, such as in industrial chemical processing applications.  We performed analyses of both 2D and 3D fluid data from experiments.

We developed a new, expanded definition of the Finite-Time Lyapunov Exponent (FTLE). From the FTLE field, which many researchers are beginning to compute as a standard tool for Lagrangian (or trajectory-based) fluid analysis, one can get a first-order picture of coherent sets, the ‘valleys’ as opposed to the ridges, of the FTLE field (the ridges have been the focus for the past 10 years, but the valleys largely ignored). 

We considered the braiding and bifurcation of almost-cyclic sets from a micromixer example, and its relation to topological chaos. The analysis of a predicting bifurcations in transport structure from transfer operators is a novel, and likely fruitful, approach to bifurcation analysis of systems. 

Dynamical systems-based causality analyses were applied to the initiation of the spread of plant disease. Convergent cross mapping and multivariate embedding causality analyses were conducted on field measurements of airborne spores of Fusarium graminearum, causal agent of FHB, from large artificial sources of inoculum over two years. Convergent cross mapping analysis identified relative humidity, solar radiation, wind speed, and air temperature as parameters influencing atmospheric spore release. 

Dynamical systems techniques were applied to the problem of gliding flight—moving horizontally downward through the air without power. Historically, gliding has been conceptualized using the idealized conditions of equilibrium, in which the net aerodynamic force on the glider balances its weight. To investigate non-equilibrium glide behavior as part of this NSF project, we developed a reduced-order model of gliding that accounts for self-similarity in the equations of motion, such that the lift and drag characteristics alone determine the glide trajectory. From analysis of velocity polar diagrams of horizontal and vertical velocity from several gliding species, we found that pitch angle, the angle between the horizontal and chord line, is a control parameter that can be exploited to modulate glide angle and glide speed. We elucidated some dynamical phenomena that occur in a universal model of non-equilibrium gliding for animals, including bifurcations, limit cycles, and a terminal velocity manifold.  Such analyses provide a new mechanism of interspecies comparison and tools to understand experimentally-measured kinematics data and theory. In addition, this analysis suggests that the lift and drag characteristics of aerial and aquatic autonomous gliders can be engineered to passively alter glide trajectories with minimal control effort.

We developed a trajectory-free approximation of phase space structures using a technique we call the trajectory divergence rate, a scalar field which locally gives the instantaneous attraction or repulsion of adjacent trajectories. This scalar field may be used to find highly attracting or repelling invariant manifolds, such as slow manifolds, to rapidly approximate hyperbolic Lagrangian coherent structures, or to provide the local stability of invariant manifolds.

In addition to training of graduate and undergraduates researchers, this project developed an interdisciplinary project-based graduate-level course exploring the frontiers of dynamical systems research, leading to new scientific research and peer-reviewed journal publications, initiated and performed by student teams. One such study was on comparing stability entropy metrics of clinically-obtainable biomechanical data to differentiate between seniors prone to falling and those that are not. The methods had a predictive ability of over 90%.

 


Last Modified: 10/05/2018
Modified by: Shane D Ross

Images (1 of )
  • Braiding in (2+1)-dimensional space-time via three almost-cyclic sets for a micromixer system where exactly periodic points no longer exist. Snapshots at intervals during a flow cycle are shown in a-f and the periodic braid in space-time is shown in g. This braid corresponds to a high mixing level.
    Shane Ross and Piyush Grover
    Creative Commons
    Shane D Ross
    Fluid mixing understood via braiding in space-time and topological entropy
  • From the FTLE field (top), we extract some ?valley floors? (black sets in (a)). These relatively coherent sets do not disperse significantly while a non-coherent set of high FTLE (gray set in (a)) does, as seen in their evolution in (b) after 1 fluid cycle of this micromixer model.
    Shane Ross and Phanindra Tallapragada
    Creative Commons
    Shane D Ross
    FTLE valley floors do not mix well
  • From vortex ring fluid experimental data, we show the Lagrangian boundary of the vortex overlaid with the vorticity field from the standard velocity field integration method (a) and our new particle tracking flow map compilation method (b).
    Shane Ross and Samuel Raben
    Creative Commons
    Shane D Ross
    Vortex ring experiment LCS extraction method comparison
  • The convergent cross mapping coefficient between candidate driver signals (meteorological variables) and response signals (spore concentration) from an agricultural experiment. Variables that increase significantly with increasing library length are the important drivers influencing spore release.
    Shane Ross and Amir BozorgMagham
    Creative Commons
    Shane D Ross
    Convergent cross mapping to determine causal agents of plant disease spread
  • In a ship dynamics problem, the boundary between capsizing and non-capsizing trajectories is the tube-like surface in this 3-D representation. The example red trajectory, lies inside the tube and capsizes. Similarly, the blue trajectory that starts outside the tube is a non-capsizing trajectory.
    Shane Ross and Shibabrat Naik
    Creative Commons
    Shane D Ross
    Tube dynamics in ship dynamics model reveal capsize boundaries
  • The terminal velocity manifold as a 2-D surface embedded in 3-D space for an airfoil. Blue (red) values indicate positive (negative) acceleration along the manifold, while the 1-D curve shows the equilibrium points of the system; stable nodes (blue), saddle points (red), and stable foci (purple).
    Shane Ross and Gary Nave
    Creative Commons
    Shane D Ross
    Terminal velocity manifold surface for gliding dynamics in extended phase space
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project was to develop a unified foundation for the theoretical and computational analysis of the phase space transport problem. "Phase space" is a set of quantifiable parameters which describe a system?s changing state or behavior. The evolution of a system?s behavior in time can be viewed as a curve or trajectory in its phase space. Many physical systems can be modeled as having an underlying dynamical or geometrical "skeleton" which organizes how all the possible behaviors are related. For systems known analytically (as a set of equations with simple mathematical functions) with simple time dependence, this skeleton consists of well-known mathematical structures such as invariant sets and sets which asymptotically approach or depart from such sets. But for systems of increasing interest which are non-periodic, based on experimental data, and observed over only a short time, there are no such structures in general. Our project sought to find appropriate analogs to these structures to expand the applicability of dynamical systems results to real-world data. Working mostly in the context of fluid flows, rigid body dynamics, and multi-body dynamics, we developed tools using geometric, probabilistic, and topological approaches, including coherent sets, almost-invariant sets, and symbolic dynamics. We considered the performance of trajectory-based, rather than vector-field-based methods for determining phase space structure, with applications to fluid experiments. We found that from sequences of particle images, e.g., from particle image velocimetry (or PIV) fluid experiments, one can directly compute the flow map and coherent structures, skipping the step of constructing a velocity field. This is useful for inertial particles which do not follow fluid velocity, such as in industrial chemical processing applications. We performed analyses of both 2D and 3D fluid data from experiments. We developed a new, expanded definition of the Finite-Time Lyapunov Exponent (FTLE). From the FTLE field, which many researchers are beginning to compute as a standard tool for Lagrangian (or trajectory-based) fluid analysis, one can get a first-order picture of coherent sets, the ?valleys? as opposed to the ridges, of the FTLE field (the ridges have been the focus for the past 10 years, but the valleys largely ignored). We considered the braiding and bifurcation of almost-cyclic sets from a micromixer example, and its relation to topological chaos. The analysis of a predicting bifurcations in transport structure from transfer operators is a novel, and likely fruitful, approach to bifurcation analysis of systems. Dynamical systems-based causality analyses were applied to the initiation of the spread of plant disease. Convergent cross mapping and multivariate embedding causality analyses were conducted on field measurements of airborne spores of Fusarium graminearum, causal agent of FHB, from large artificial sources of inoculum over two years. Convergent cross mapping analysis identified relative humidity, solar radiation, wind speed, and air temperature as parameters influencing atmospheric spore release. Dynamical systems techniques were applied to the problem of gliding flight—moving horizontally downward through the air without power. Historically, gliding has been conceptualized using the idealized conditions of equilibrium, in which the net aerodynamic force on the glider balances its weight. To investigate non-equilibrium glide behavior as part of this NSF project, we developed a reduced-order model of gliding that accounts for self-similarity in the equations of motion, such that the lift and drag characteristics alone determine the glide trajectory. From analysis of velocity polar diagrams of horizontal and vertical velocity from several gliding species, we found that pitch angle, the angle between the horizontal and chord line, is a control parameter that can be exploited to modulate glide angle and glide speed. We elucidated some dynamical phenomena that occur in a universal model of non-equilibrium gliding for animals, including bifurcations, limit cycles, and a terminal velocity manifold. Such analyses provide a new mechanism of interspecies comparison and tools to understand experimentally-measured kinematics data and theory. In addition, this analysis suggests that the lift and drag characteristics of aerial and aquatic autonomous gliders can be engineered to passively alter glide trajectories with minimal control effort. We developed a trajectory-free approximation of phase space structures using a technique we call the trajectory divergence rate, a scalar field which locally gives the instantaneous attraction or repulsion of adjacent trajectories. This scalar field may be used to find highly attracting or repelling invariant manifolds, such as slow manifolds, to rapidly approximate hyperbolic Lagrangian coherent structures, or to provide the local stability of invariant manifolds. In addition to training of graduate and undergraduates researchers, this project developed an interdisciplinary project-based graduate-level course exploring the frontiers of dynamical systems research, leading to new scientific research and peer-reviewed journal publications, initiated and performed by student teams. One such study was on comparing stability entropy metrics of clinically-obtainable biomechanical data to differentiate between seniors prone to falling and those that are not. The methods had a predictive ability of over 90%. Last Modified: 10/05/2018 Submitted by: Shane D Ross
